subject: RE: [junit] Some questions about JUnit 4
msgSnippet: ... No. ... In theory, no. In practice, test classes are run in the order they are passed and test methods are run in declaration order. ...
messageBody:
> -----Original Message-----
> From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On
> Behalf Of Elliotte Harold
> Sent: Saturday, July 30, 2005 11:05 AM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: [junit] Some questions about JUnit 4
>
> I've been experimenting with JUnit 4 and mostly I like it. I
> do have a
> few questions:
>
> 1. If there are multiple @Before annotated methods in a
> class, are any
> guarantees made about what order they are invoked in? Same
> question for
> @After, @BeforeClass, and @AfterClass.

No.

>
> 2. Is there any way to control the order in which tests are
> run? Or is
> that pretty much still up to the test runner like in JUnit 3?

In theory, no. In practice, test classes are run in the order they are
passed and test methods are run in declaration order.

>
> 3. Is there any equivalent to the suite() method in JUnit 3?
> i.e. how do
> I bundle up several different test classes so they can be run
> as a group?

JUnitCore.run(Class... classes) will run several classes' worth of tests.

>
> 4. Java 5 is obviously required to build JUnit 4. Can it
> nonetheless run
> in Java 1.4? or is Java 5 pretty much required for anything that uses
> JUnit 4?

Java 5 is required.

>
> 5. The GUI test runners don't appear to be in Version4 CVS. Will they
> return at some point?

We don't have any plans to provide GUI test runners.

>
> 6. Why are Assert.failSame, Assert.failNotSame,
> Assert.failNotEquals(),
> and Assert.format now public?

The change was inadvertent.

Sincerely yours,

Kent Beck
Three Rivers Institute
